text: [Music]
when you're migrating to aws
you need to develop a clear plan a plan
can help you avoid roadblocks in the
future
and guide you through what can be a
complicated process to help you
formulate your plan
aws provides the aws migration hub
this hub provides you with information
tooling and a way to track the progress
of your migration
in this video however i'm going to dive
a little deeper into two tools that will
help you when migrating.net applications
and microsoft workloads to aws
firstly i'll look at cloud endure then
i'll use the windows web application
migration assistant
cloud enduro is the first tool that i'm
going to show you it takes copies of
your servers and then moves them over to
aws
your servers can be physical virtual or
cloud-based the second tool i'll show
you is the windows web application
migration assistant
it's an interactive powershell utility
that migrates asp.net and asp.net core
applications
from windows servers to aws elastic
beanstalk the migration assistant is
able to migrate an entire website
and its configuration to elastic
beanstalk with minimal or no changes to
the application
after the system migrates the
application elastic beanstock
automatically handles auto scaling
application health monitoring and
applying all the patches and updates to
the underlying platform
let me show you the first tool called
cloud endure i'm going to use it to
migrate two
virtual machines over to aws one of
these virtual machines runs my website
which sits on top of internet
information server or iis this is more
commonly known
and the other is my database server that
runs sql server
2016 and contains a single database
if i head over to the aws product page
for cloud and draw you'll see there's
lots of information about
what the product does and some customer
examples at the bottom here
it also contains information about
obtaining a free license
now i've already clicked on this button
to obtain my free cloud enduro licenses
this process involves creating a cloud
into your account and then associating
that with your aws account this will
then
activate a license so you're able to
conduct migrations from your server's
current locations into aws
as i've already registered i can log
into my account and start migration
project
to create a project i select the little
plus sign on the left
i give my migration project a name such
as full site migration
and select the this is a migration
project
the target infrastructure is
automatically set to be aws and my
license details are pre-filled
showing that i've a license that's good
to migrate ten thousand machines
i then click on the create project
i now begin to set up my project i need
to give cloud endure permission to be
able to operate and create
infrastructure
in my aws account to do this i'm going
to need to create a user
and then give that user a set of
permissions here are the policy
permissions that cloud engineer needs
i copy this information so i can use it
in a second
i head over to the aws identity and
access management console
which is often shortened to the im
console and click create policy
on this json tab i paste the policy that
was suggested by cloud endure
and then click on review policy
i give my policy the name cloud endure
policy and fill in the description with
something like
policy required by clouding i look at
the permissions that this policy is
granting and i'm happy with it also i
click
create policy
now navigate to the users section of the
im console and click
add user i give my user a name cloud
endure user
and give it programmatic access
click to go to the permission screen i
select
attach existing policies directly and
search for the cloud endure policy
i select the policy and then click next
and then next again and then finally
click create user
once the user is created i'm giving the
access key id
and the secret access key which i'll
need to add to my migration project
back in the cloud into your console i
can paste the access key and the secret
into my project and save so that my
project can now use those credentials to
create infrastructure
inside my account i also need to provide
some more information to set up the
project
i select the migration source as other
infrastructure because i'm migrating
some virtual machines
then i select the target aws region as
aws
eu stockholm cloud enduro user console
allows me to configure variety of other
settings as well
i can select what instance size i want
to use for the replication server
there's also options for subnet security
group vpn
or direct connect usage and encryption
i'm going to leave all these for the
moment one thing i will do is add a tag
so that i can easily identify any of the
infrastructure that's been added by
cloud endure
i'll set the tags key to cloud endure
and the value is true
after i save my replication settings
cloud endure prompts me to install the
cloud endure agent on my source machines
in my example the source machines
consist of a web server
and a microsoft sql server running my
applications database
there are some instructions to install
the agent you can do this manually on
each machine by downloading this
executable
and then running this command i actually
wrote this up as a powershell script and
executed it across both the machines
using a remote powershell execution tool
after the agent installation completes
cloud endure adds my source machines to
the cloud enduro user console
from there my source machines undergo
several initial replication steps
data replication consists of two stages
initial sync
and continuous data replication during
initial sync
cloud endure copies all of the content
from the source disks
on the onto the elastic block store
volumes
these are often called ebs volumes which
are located
in the staging area after initial sync
completes
continuous data replication begins
tracking my source machines
and replicating new data rights to the
staging ebs volumes
continuous data replication makes sure
that my staging area
always has the most up-to-date copy of
my source machines
when the data replication progress
status column reads
continuous data replication and the
migration lifecycle
status column reads ready for testing
initial sync
is complete these statuses indicate that
the machines are functioning correctly
and are ready for testing and migration
replication took around an hour for
these two machines and if i click on the
sql server and then look at the source
tab you can see that all the details of
my source machine
have been captured including all of the
installed applications
and all of the running services to test
how my machines run on aws i configure
the
target machine blueprint this blueprint
is a set of configurations that define
where and how the target machines
are launched and provisioned such as
target subnet security groups
instance types volume type and tags
i'll leave this all on the defaults and
because of this i'll get a warning
suggestion that it's probably best to
use
these defaults only in testing and not
in production as they expose a few
potentially unnecessary ports
i click on ok i go through the same
process for the other machines
and now i'm ready to test i recommend
performing a test at least two weeks
before migrating your source machines
to give you enough time to identify
potential problems and resolve them
before you perform the actual cutover
to launch my machines in test mode i
select both my machines then click
the launch to target machines button and
choose
test mode cloud enduro then confirms
what i'm going to do
and i click on ok which initializes the
launch of two new instances
in the aws stockholm region i can then
click on the job progress tab to see how
the test launch is going it took about
12 minutes for my machines to launch
i can explore my machine in the cloud
endure and check out the blueprint
details which show
things like the private ip address
there's also a new tab called target
that contains information such as
public ip address and the instance id
i would now ordinarily perform a test on
the machines to make sure that the apps
running on them
are working as expected after i
completed testing my machines continued
to be
in continuous date replication mode
until the scheduled cut over window
let's pretend i'm happy with the
machines and they're running as
i would expect them to i would now
perform a cut over
in the dashboard it now says my two
machines are ready so i select both my
machines
and then launch two target machines and
this time select cut over mode
again i see the progress by clicking on
the job progress
and selecting the cut over launch job
in this situation it took about 15
minutes for the job to complete
so here are all the logs and you can see
that the job here is finished
if i now check the sql machine i can see
that its type has been set to cut over
and all the details are in there
i can now make any configuration
adjustments perform user acceptance
testing
on the website and finally redirect my
users to the new environment
to clear things up i would remove the
cloud into your agent from the source
machines and the cloud endure user
console
i could then decommission my source
machines my web server and my database
are now live however in aws i find it
better to run
asp.net websites on elastic beanstalk
rather than on
an ec2 instance that i manage myself i
will now show you how to use an open
source tool called the windows web
application migration assistant for aws
elastic beanstalk
which is an alternative way to move an
asp.net web application to aws
the migration assistant is available as
an open source project on github
and is able to migrate an entire website
and its configuration to elastic
beanstalk with minimal
or no code changes to the application
after the assistant migrates the
application elastic beanstalk
automatically handles the ongoing
details
of capacity provisioning load balancing
auto scaling
application health monitoring and
applying patches and updates to the
underlying platform
basically you don't need to worry about
managing the underlying ec2 instances
i'm going to make a remote desktop
connection into my web application
server
and load up a powershell prompt first i
need to install the aws powershell
module so i run the command
install module aws powershell
sometimes the installation will fail on
all the servers running
old versions of windows server this is
due to the version of transport layer
security or tls that powershell uses by
default
you get around this issue by running the
following command net dot service point
manager
security protocol equals net.security
protocol type
tls12 next i install the web
administration module for powershell by
running the command
import module web administration much
like i did earlier i've created a user
inside of aws identity and access
management that has the policies
aws elastic beanstalk full access and
i am read only access
now that i have the security credentials
for this user i can now set the
credentials for the powershell session
you may or not need the dash profile
location parameter
i've noticed that sometimes without it
certain virtual machines
do not work as expected i will now use
the invoke web request command to pull
down from the internet
the latest version of the windows web
application migration assistant tool
and save it to the current folder as
tool dot
zip i then use
expand archive to expand this zip folder
i navigate to where the application has
been extracted to
from the tool which is actually a
powershell script called migrate ias
website to elasticbeanstalk.ps1
i'm now prompted by the application for
some information it asks what region i
want to migrate the application to i
type eu north 1 which is the stockholm
region
the tool then looks at my iis server and
sees i have two websites i choose to
migrate the second website
this takes a little time i'm then asked
to give the website a name
choose a server type to run it on and
whether i want the application to be
load balanced
there is also a step here that asks if i
want to update any aws connection
strings and provide new database
connection strings
i've admitted this from the video for
security reasons
the tool will then begin to upload the
local site to aws
it took around six minutes for this site
to be migrated when it's finished
the tool logs a url for the load
balanced website
the web application has now been moved
and if i visit the url you can see
that the website is now available at
that new url also i should mention
i've updated the connection strings of
this website to point to the database
that i migrated earlier using
the cloud endure tool in this video i
showed you how to re-host an on-premises
workload to aws using cloud engineer
migration
cloud endure automatically converts your
machines from any source infrastructure
to aws i then went on to show you
an alternative method to migrate an
asp.net application over to aws elastic
beanstalk
with lots of information and
documentation about how to migrate your
application
check out the aws migration hub to start
your migration journey
see you soon happy migrating
